body:
Hello

I have the same problem. Geforce 3080 10GB does not train more than a few iterations.
I tried my best to debug and it completes a few iterations but stops in this call: model.train_one_iter() and never finishes.

Few things to note:
1. When loading XSEG on a Geforce 3080 10GB it uses ALL the VRAM. I have to lower the batch_size to 2, to have it even start. I used to run XSEG on a Geforce 1060 6GB and it would run fine at batch 8. 

Could this be some VRAM over allocation problem?

2. Also worth of note, CPU training works fine.

GPU: Geforce 3080 10GB.
Tensorflow-gpu  2.4.0rc3
Driver 457.51
CUDA 11.1
CUDNN 11.1
OS: Windows 10 20H2

DFL build, is the latest RTX 3000 build with the "_internal\DeepFaceLab" folder mirrored from latest github comit and latest CUDNN .dll files.

> Hello
> 
> I have the same problem. Geforce 3080 10GB does not train more than a few iterations.
> I tried my best to debug and it completes a few iterations but stops in this call: model.train_one_iter() and never finishes.
> 
> Few things to note:
> 
> 1. When loading XSEG on a Geforce 3080 10GB it uses ALL the VRAM. I have to lower the batch_size to 2, to have it even start. I used to run XSEG on a Geforce 1060 6GB and it would run fine at batch 8.
> 
> Could this be some VRAM over allocation problem?
> 
> 1. Also worth of note, CPU training works fine.
> 
> GPU: Geforce 3080 10GB.
> Tensorflow-gpu 2.4.0rc3
> Driver 457.51
> CUDA 11.1
> CUDNN 11.1
> OS: Windows 10 20H2
> 
> DFL build, is the latest RTX 3000 build with the "_internal\DeepFaceLab" folder mirrored from latest github comit and latest CUDNN .dll files.

I follow ur way about batch_size to 2 . But it still can't work. I try use cpu to run Xseg train , it can work

it is a TF2.4.0 issue.

Current 2080TI build based on tf 2.3.1 works fine.

Thanks for the reply sir.

So would this issue be auto resolved once the TF 2.4 is released as a stable release?

Did you see that TensorFlow 2.4.0 adds support for TF32 format for Ampere based GPUs; it is enabled by default. Does Deepfacelab support this, without any code changes?

> So would this issue be auto resolved once the TF 2.4 is released as a stable release?

it is not gauranteed.
TF is a shit last years.

This problem can be solved, but sometimes it recurs. 

you should use CUDA11.1 files to replace the files in CUDA folder. If the file under CUDA is _10 and cudA11.1 is _11, rename _11 to _10 and replace the file. Cputi64_2020.1.1.1.dll is processed in the same way.

The Cudnn folder is also processed this way.

refer to cuda11.1 release node : Enhanced CUDA compatibility across minor releases of CUDA will enable CUDA applications to be compatible with all versions of a particular CUDA major release.

the legacy is that DFL may stuck, when the GPU’s cuda is fully loaded.

gpu: msi rtx 3090
Driver: 457
Tensorflow: 2.4.0rc4
@marsmana I checked, it does not fix the problem.
Checked 11.1.1  . Same it does not fix the problem with tf2.4.0rc4

tf2.4.0rc4 is just a super buggy shit.
I doubt they will fix the problem.
@marsmana can you give me access to your comp? I want to test something. Telegram me @iperov
nevermind, will test on other comp
Got the same issues on rtx3090 with xseg
@gytters I know about the problem. It is reproducable. But it is an tensorflow issue. Because the same code on tf 2.3.1 works fine.

Anyone else notice that XSEG on the TF 2.4 seems to use insane amounts of VRAM. Even though XSEG does not complete a iteration. I have to use batch size 2 on a Geforce 3080 10GB. I used to be able to start XSEG with batch size 8 with only 6GB ram on a 1060 card. 

I wonder if this is related. Perhaps a VRAM allocation error in TF 2.4?

some reports says Hardware-accelerated GPU scheduling, which is in “ default graphics setting ”, can solve the problem. 
I have test it, it works.

but, it doesn’t solve the problem of using and abnormal vram.
